message: For me it's graphlog.  I can't make sense of repositories containing branches/merges without it.
@alfborge bisect has been a built-in command since 1.0 :)
For me, I always enable bisect and color.
@stevelosh Indeed, see how much attention I've been paying. :)
I'm just waiting for someone to say fetch, so I can try to shame them.  It's been that sort of a day in #mercurial IRC. :)
@Ry4an OK, I'll bite; fetch and mq (although I can live w/o fetch since pull/update is not exactly difficult)
shelve, and currently (unfortunately) hgsubversion
God... graphlog for sure then mq/rebase/purge. Also: Steve's terminal colored styles...
definitely "record". i love the possibility to review my changes bit for bit before checking in.
record, mq and graphlog are definitely some I no longer can live without. Especially on Windows and/or when you work with http(s) repositories, mercurial_keyring is also absolutely indispensable
@asolovyov Too bad that colors doesn't really work with Powershell :-(
graphlog, bookmarks, mq, crecord, schemes, pager, color. :P Hm, and progress, it's really nice. :)

@asolovyov You'll have to live without the bookmarks extension soon -- it went into core yesterday!  The March 1st release will have it not as a shipped extension (enabled or not) but as a built-in feature. :)

@Ry4an yeah, I know. And I'm a bit sad, because no one has answered to my mail to mercurial-devel about tracking remote bookmarks: http://selenic.com/pipermail/mercurial-devel/2011-February/027991.html
ah, and bookmarks
hgsubversion, hggit, rebase, mq, collapse, transplant, graphlog...
mq and graphlog for sure.. sounds like there are quite a few others worth dabbling with
To those that use bookmarks: its function seems similar in purpose to mq, so how does that integrate with your workflow (seeing that many of you use both).
pbraaaaanch!! ;)
color, extdiff, graphlog, httprelay (shameless plug here)
hgview - http://www.logilab.org/project/hgview
@alfborge shouldn't the title be "Extensions I just _can't_ live without"?
Nobody's mentioned: histedit, zeroconf, purge, progress, or my favorite autopager.
I think autopager is superfluous if you set "LESS=-FSRXi" in your .bashrc and use "less" as your pager. Perhaps it's useful if you're using a less configurable pager.
@james4k well, I use mq to contribute to Mercurial and to handle some patches which I don't want to see in upstream, and bookmarks are main way of development at my work
